hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Height | Number of Plants
- | - 
$14\dfrac12\text{ in}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid\mid = 7$ plants
$14\dfrac34\text{ in}$| ${\mid\mid\mid}=3$ plants
$15\dfrac14\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid\mid}=4$ plants
$15\dfrac12\text{ in}$| $\mid\mid=2$ plants
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{4}\text { in}}$.

There were $7$ plants that measured a height of $\blueD{14\dfrac12\text { in}}$.  

So, we place $7$ dots over $\blueD{14\dfrac12}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (inches) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 14, 15, and 16. Three unlabeled tick marks appear in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 7 dots above the second unlabeled tick mark after 14. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (inches) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 14, 15, and 16. Three unlabeled tick marks appear in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 7 dots above the second unlabeled tick mark after 14, 3 dots above the third unlabeled tick mark after 14, 4 dots above the first unlabeled tick mark after 15, and 2 dots above the second unlabeled tick mark after 15. !

question.content:
On Monday, Ms. Kellis and her class planted some bean seeds.  On Friday, they measured the height of their new plants to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4} \text{ in}$. 

Height | Number of Plants
- | - 
$14\dfrac12\text{ in}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid\mid$
$14\dfrac34\text{ in}$| ${\mid\mid\mid}$
$15\dfrac14\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid\mid}$
$15\dfrac12\text{ in}$| $\mid\mid$

**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**     
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]
